item.title: Buy More Starbucks
item.dc:creator: me@drewteichman.com
item.content:encoded:
Starbucks is a company that really needs no introduction, especially given that this is our second go-around. Allow me though to work in a bit of a golf analogy (as the snow flies outside the window) to outline our thought process that surrounded re-recommending this global behemoth.

For whatever reason, the collection of ideas that surfaced among the team for this month’s U.S. recommendation took the form of a 280-yard par 4 in the mind of yours truly. The golfers out there will know that this kind of approximate yardage generally represents a hole that can be played two ways.

One way is to pull out the driver, swing with all of one’s might, and try to knock it on the green, setting up what’s likely to be a lengthy eagle putt—at best. It’s a “highest risk/highest reward” type scenario. The other way to play is to hit the ball 160 yards or so into the fairway, then play a nice full wedge into the green, ideally setting up a makeable birdie putt—lower risk but still high reward.

You see, it takes all shapes and sizes to build a portfolio. The same goes for the game of golf, where you need to be able to apply any number of shots under all kinds of scenarios. In our opinion though, all portfolios need foundation-like positions from which to build. These generally fit under the “lower risk/high reward” sweet spot—a sweet spot often reserved for the very best companies in the world, of which [stocks type="bar" symbol="SBUX" display="Starbucks"] (NASDAQ:SBUX) certainly counts itself.

A few “drive-the-green” ideas were kicked around by the team, but in the end, we’re more than settled with the more conservative, yet potentially very rewarding idea that is Starbucks.

Recap

Our thesis is very much as it was in our first recommendation, but after a quick review, we’re going to drill into what continues to evolve as the big opportunity in front of this company, along with one metric that we think will support this stock very nicely under more adverse market conditions.

Much of our original thesis was centred on the international opportunity in front of Starbucks, and this will be the area that we’re going to dive into in a moment.

First though, I’d like to highlight that what we termed “arguably the largest risk shareholders face” in the original recommendation back in October 2016 has, in some respects, occurred. That risk was the departure of founder, then CEO, and significant shareholder ($2.1 billion worth) Howard Schultz. Now, “departure” probably isn’t the right word, as Schultz remains the executive chairman and has taken the development of higher-end Starbucks shops—Starbucks Reserve Roastery—under his wing. But he is no longer the company’s CEO.

The company’s former COO, Kevin Johnson, has moved into the corner suite, so to speak, and for better or worse, the market more or less gave this development a collective shrug. Perhaps it’d have been a different story if Schultz had left all together, but regardless, we like it when perceived risks don’t turn out as badly as imagined.

The Opportunity

While Schultz has his sleeves rolled up in developing the Roastery angle—an immaterial piece at this stage—the opportunity that we’ll focus on is the one that exists in China.

This is a company that throughout its life has been absolutely tremendous at generating an outsized return on its capital (relative to much of the business world). And that capital cannon, if you will, is currently pointed straight in the direction of China, where it was recently reported that a new Starbucks is opening every 15 hours!

At the end of the last quarter, Starbucks had almost 3,000 stores in China, 550 more than at the beginning of 2017 and well on track to achieve its goal of 5,000 by 2020. The company has spent the better part of two decades crafting the perfect coffeehouse experience in China. These are efforts that are set to pay off in a major way over the next several years. Looking out further, Schultz believes Starbucks’s business in China will eventually exceed the company’s U.S. business, and he is on the record stating, “We are building one of the most respected and iconic brands in the country … I believe China will be as large, or larger, than the U.S. business in the future.”

Should this occur, we believe the current stock price represents a fantastic point of entry.

One Key Metric

Historically, Starbucks has more or less represented the definition of a growth company—with the returns to prove it. And given the China opportunity especially, Starbucks remains firmly in growth mode. However, while the growth engine continues to purr, Starbucks has also become not just a dividend payer, but a dividend grower. And currently, the yield that’s on offer is about as good as it’s ever been at 2.1% or so.

Since instituting a dividend in 2010, Starbucks has increased its annual payouts from $0.18 to the current $1.20 per share. This represents a payout ratio of just 55% of trailing 12-month free cash flow, which indicates that we can expect this dividend growth to continue. Particularly when we consider the company spent about $2 billion repurchasing its stock during the last fiscal year. Recall: these folks know what they’re doing when it comes to capital allocation.

How this serves as potential support for the stock is that based on history, there’s little justification for Starbucks to provide investors with a dividend yield that’s much higher than it currently stands. If the stock sells off for any reason, that yield will move higher, but that, in turn, is likely to attract buyers, keeping the slide in check.

Turning this around, should the stock return to a more mean-like yield of 1.5%, the stock price would have to be $80—40% higher than the current level. And if the dividend payment continues higher—a likely scenario, in our opinion—so too does the potential for capital appreciation based on this metric alone.

Risks and Considerations

Similar risks and considerations remain as they were in our first recommendation. Short term, the market is ever focused on the company’s same-store-sales (SSS) figure, and therefore, quarterly results can cause the stock to get a bit whippy. We pay this no mind.

Bigger picture, rapid growth—regardless of the industry—is a challenge. The execution risk associated with something like coffee versus say, burritos (ahem, Chipotle) is seemingly far less and more focused on marketing/brand awareness, but no doubt, Starbucks could stub a toe, or three, as it pursues this Chinese opportunity. We’ll be mindful of this as we go, but to this point, it’s been a relatively pain-free expansion.

Foolish Bottom Line

Because we’re so aligned with the original recommendation, I’m going to borrow from the close. If we cared a lick about what the SSS print might be in the next quarter or a year from now, I’m not sure we’d be recommending this company. But for those willing to ignore the noise and recognize the opportunity that’s in front of this company, and the ground work in place to ensure it comes to fruition, this is every bit as good a time to begin building a position as it was in October 2016. And similar to the intro note, if you’re moving capital from more speculative positions to begin this build, even better. While the market is focused on the here and now, we see great things transpiring for both the company and the stock for the next decade and beyond. And thus we’re very happy to be ordering up another round of shares. Join us!

item.title: Buy Fortis
item.dc:creator: me@drewteichman.com
item.content:encoded:
Dividend stock investing is relatively simple to learn for all walks of life. So, no matter if you are newly retired, just had a kid, or are a high school student who wants to invest the savings from your summer job, dividend investing can work beautifully for you.

There are thousands of stocks to choose from. To save time and immediately filter for potential quality dividend stocks, start selecting from the Canadian Dividend Aristocrat list. This list consists of dividend stocks that have increased their dividends for at least five years.

Learn from dividend stock Fortis

One of the best examples for learning is Fortis (TSX:FTS)(NYSE:FTS) stock. The dividend stock is quality in a number of ways.

First, it has one of the longest streaks of dividend growth among public Canadian stocks. It has raised its dividend for almost half a century!

Second, by observing its earnings history for at least the past 10 years, which covers an economic cycle, we find out that it has highly stable earnings. Specifically, its earnings per share only dropped in one year — and only by 1%. There was one year where its earnings were flat, while the other years witnessed earnings growth. This means that the dividend stock could maintain its dividend as long as it keeps a sustainable payout ratio.

Because of its highly stable earnings, Fortis’s payout ratio of about 75% of earnings is sufficient to protect its dividend.

Fortis stock’s 10-year dividend-growth rate is 5.6%. It targets to increase its payout by about 6% per year through 2025. The consistent rate of 5-6% signifies the predictability of the regulated electric and gas utility. Management didn’t just project it for the next two years, which, again, suggests a low-risk, highly predictable business.

Digging a little deeper into the business, you can see why it’s low risk. It’s a regulated utility with defined returns on equity on its assets. Moreover, it is largely made of distribution and transmission assets that have little uncertainty. Its $19.6 billion 2021-2025 capital plan includes two-thirds of distribution and transmission projects, which supports the overweight in those assets. Management sees this capital plan driving low-risk rate base growth of roughly 6%, which matches with the projected dividend-growth rate.

Fortis stock’s valuation 

You want to pay for a low valuation to maximize your yield and total returns. However, the market rarely provides opportunities to buy Fortis stock at a bargain. In fact, the dividend stock commands a premium valuation because of its low risk and high quality.

For example, its long-term normal price-to-earnings ratio (P/E) is about 19.4. You would be very lucky to pick up some Fortis shares at a P/E of about 18, which is approximately $49 per share based on this year’s estimated earnings.

With a dividend stock as low uncertainty as Fortis, you can use its recent yield history as a guide for when to buy. Its five-year yield history suggests that you should buy the stock whenever it yields +4%.

FTS Dividend Yield data by YCharts.

The Foolish investor takeaway

New investors can choose low-risk, quality dividend stocks from the Canadian Dividend Aristocrat list to begin their dividend investing journey. With a focus on dividend safety, dividend growth, business quality, and valuation, you should be able to generate long-term returns of +7% while earning a growing dividend income.

Unlock our top stocks for the “T288 era”

We now believe that a game-changing announcement by Apple in a matter of weeks could launch nothing less than a whole new era of technology — the “T288 era.”

With estimates believing this era could grow to US$7 trillion in annual sales — that’s 8x BIGGER than last year’s e-commerce sales…

The Motley Fool has produced a full investing plan to try taking full advantage of what Deloitte calls “the next digital transformation.”

Click below to learn more!

Specifically, its earnings per share only dropped in one year — and only by 1%. There was one year where its earnings were flat, while the other years witnessed earnings growth. This means that the dividend stock could maintain its dividend as long as it keeps a sustainable payout ratio.

Because of its highly stable earnings, Fortis’s payout ratio of about 75% of earnings is sufficient to protect its dividend.

Fortis stock’s 10-year dividend-growth rate is 5.6%. It targets to increase its payout by about 6% per year through 2025. The consistent rate of 5-6% signifies the predictability of the regulated electric and gas utility. Management didn’t just project it for the next two years, which, again, suggests a low-risk, highly predictable business.

Digging a little deeper into the business, you can see why it’s low risk. It’s a regulated utility with defined returns on equity on its assets. Moreover, it is largely made of distribution and transmission assets that have little uncertainty. Its $19.6 billion 2021-2025 capital plan includes two-thirds of distribution and transmission projects, which supports the overweight in those assets. Management sees this capital plan driving low-risk rate base growth of roughly 6%, which matches with the projected dividend-growth rate.

Fortis stock’s valuation 

You want to pay for a low valuation to maximize your yield and total returns. However, the market rarely provides opportunities to buy Fortis stock at a bargain. In fact, the dividend stock commands a premium valuation because of its low risk and high quality.

For example, its long-term normal price-to-earnings ratio (P/E) is about 19.4. You would be very lucky to pick up some Fortis shares at a P/E of about 18, which is approximately $49 per share based on this year’s estimated earnings.

With a dividend stock as low uncertainty as Fortis, you can use its recent yield history as a guide for when to buy. Its five-year yield history suggests that you should buy the stock whenever it yields +4%.

FTS Dividend Yield data by YCharts.

The Foolish investor takeaway

New investors can choose low-risk, quality dividend stocks from the Canadian Dividend Aristocrat list to begin their dividend investing journey. With a focus on dividend safety, dividend growth, business quality, and valuation, you should be able to generate long-term returns of +7% while earning a growing dividend income.

item.title: Buy More Nvidia
item.dc:creator: me@drewteichman.com
item.content:encoded:
Both Advanced Micro Devices (NASDAQ:AMD) and Nvidia (NASDAQ:NVDA) have had an extremely positive week, with shares of AMD reaching all-time highs during open market hours on August 4 and Nvidia shares close to the same goal. In today's video I look at the recent news that could be driving this positive momentum for both AMD and Nvidia. Here are some highlights from the video: 

  1. On July 26 AMD reported strong earnings, which has triggered numerous analysts to increase the price targets for AMD. Nvidia has also seen increased price target hikes even though its earnings are scheduled for August 16, 2021. Analysts may be bullish for Nvidia after AMD reported a strong quarter. 
  2. On August 3 AMD announced that its new high-performance graphics cards are now available on Apple's (NASDAQ:AAPL) Mac Pros. On July 29 AMD also announced the release date of its budget-friendly gaming graphics card. 
  3. On August 2 Nvidia announced the availability of its Base Command Platform, a product aimed at enterprise companies that want instant access to powerful computing. The service is a subscription-based model starting at $90,000 a month with a three-month minimum contract. 

Click the video below for my full thoughts and analysis. 

*Stock prices used were the midday prices of August 4, 2021. The video was published on August 4, 2021.

Click the video below for my full thoughts and analysis. 

*Stock prices used were the midday prices of August 4, 2021. The video was published on August 4, 2021.

item.title: Buy Telus
item.dc:creator: me@drewteichman.com
item.content:encoded:
TELUS (TSX:T)(NYSE:TU) has a very diverse portfolio of services and solutions and recently reported higher revenues. This was driven by a combination of TELUS’ smart technology and security solutions, the resilient performance of TELUS’ TI University in the Philippines, increased revenues from the hyper-scaling of TELUS’  virtual care solutions, and the growing scale of TELUS Agriculture.

Deriving shareholder value

Further, TELUS’ has been deriving shareholder value from the company’s leadership in social capitalism. Even in challenging times, TELUS’ has consistently returned significant capital to shareholders, while maintaining a robust balance sheet, making generational investments in advanced broadband technologies, and advancing the company’s social purpose through community investment and philanthropy.

In the first quarter of 2020, after thoughtfully weighing the interests of TELUS’s many stakeholders, alongside the countless initiatives TELUS undertook in response to the health crisis, the company decided to defer a scheduled dividend increase.

However, in November, TELUS was able to resume the company’s multi-year dividend growth program with a seven percent increase to the company’s annualized dividend.

Consistent performance and cash flow generation

This dividend increase was a reflection of TELUS’s confidence in the company’s strong and consistent performance and cash flow generation. This was its 19th dividend increase since the establishment of the company’s first three-year program a decade ago. Notably, since 2004, TELUS has returned over $19 billion to shareholders, including $14 billion in dividends, representing approximately $15 per share.

TELUS understands the importance of dividend income to the millions of citizens who own TELUS shares, including middle-income Canadians and pensioners who rely on this form of income for a livelihood, as these investments help consumers and businesses thrive. Since 2000, TELUS has paid approximately $46 billion in total tax and spectrum remittances to the company’s federal, provincial and municipal governments.

Supporting fiscal investments

These funds support fiscal investments in roads and bridges, public education, healthcare, cultural pursuits, and national defence. In several ways, TELUS continues to sustain industry leadership relative to the company’s global peers and delivers sustainable results for the benefit of the many stakeholders it serves.

Since the end of 1999 through to 2021, TELUS generated a total shareholder return of 600 percent, 327 points higher than the return for the Canadian stock market index of 273 percent, and dramatically overshadowed the world communication services index return of 56 percent over the same period.

Moreover, over the past one, three, five, 10, and 15 years, TELUS surpassed the Canadian stock market index return by three percent, seven percent, 14 percent, 183 percent, and 175 percent, respectively.

Leading operational and financial results

Furthermore, TELUS’ leadership in customer service, network excellence, investor value creation, and social capitalism differentiates it from the company’s peers, globally. As the world looks ahead toward a period of economic and social recovery and inspired by the TELUS team’s strong performance in 2020, TELUS has established new community giving, social impact, and financial targets for the year.

Overall, TELUS looks all set to continue delivering leading operational and financial results. This should lead to a higher valuation and stock price. Long-term shareholders could handsomely benefit from income and capital appreciation.
